{{EngvarB|date=September 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2015}} {{Use Australian English|date=February 2018}} {{Infobox person |name = Man Haron Monis |image = File:Man Haron Monis.jpeg |birth_name = Mohammad-Hassan Manteghi Borujerdi{{cite news|first=Rana|last=Rahimpour|title=A Bloody End to 16 Hours of Hostage taking in Sydney|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/persian/world/2014/12/141215_l93_sydney_end|work=[[BBC Persian]]|language=Persian|date=15 December 2014|accessdate=16 December 2014}} |birth_date = {{birth date|1964|5|19|df=y}} |birth_place = [[Borujerd]], [[Iran]] |death_date = {{death date and age|df=y|2014|12|16|1964|5|19}} |death_place = [[Sydney]], [[New South Wales]], [[Australia]] |death_cause = [[Ballistic trauma]] |residence = [[Bexley North, New South Wales]], Australia |criminal_charge= {{plainlist|*'''Iran''':
[[Violent crime]], [[fraud]]; [[fugitive|wanted]] since 1996.
*'''Australia''':
Postal harassment (convicted), [[sexual assault]]s, [[accessory to murder]] }} |criminal_status = Died while awaiting trial in Australia |spouse = Amirah Droudis |website = {{unbulleted list |{{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141213222441/http://www.sheikhharon.com/ |date=13 December 2014 |title=Personal website }} }} |known for = Responsible for the [[2014 Sydney hostage crisis]] }} '''Man Haron Monis''' born '''Mohammed Hassan Manteghi Borujerdi''' (19 May 1964 – 16 December 2014) was an Iranian-born refugee and Australian citizen{{cite news |url= http://www.theaustralian.com.au/in-depth/sydney-siege-deranged-gunman-man-haron-monis-granted-citizenship-in-2004/story-fnqxbywy-1227158617685 |title= 'Deranged' Monis granted citizenship in 2004 |work= The Australian |date= 17 December 2014 |author= Bita, Natasha |publisher= News Limited |subscription= yes |accessdate= 17 December 2014}} {{Closed access}} who took hostages in [[2014 Sydney hostage crisis|a siege at the Lindt Chocolate Café]] at [[Martin Place]], [[Sydney]] on 15 December 2014,{{cite news |url= http://www.theage.com.au/nsw/martin-place-sydney-siege-gunman-identified-as-man-haron-monis-20141215-127sxt.html |last1= Ralston |first1= Nick |title= Martin Place, Sydney siege gunman identified as Man Haron Monis |work= [[The Age]] |date= 15 December 2015 |publisher= Fairfax Media |accessdate= 15 December 2014}} lasting for 17 hours, until the early hours of the following morning. The siege resulted in the death of Monis and two hostages.{{cite news |url= http://news.smh.com.au/breaking-news-national/grieving-sydney-shows-heart-after-siege-20141216-3mmkp.html |title= Grieving Sydney shows heart after siege |work= [[The Sydney Morning Herald]] |date= 16 December 2014 |last= Trute |first= Peter |publisher= Fairfax Media |accessdate= 16 December 2014}}{{cite news |last= Benjamin |first= Shanthi |url= http://www.sbs.com.au/news/article/2014/12/16/sydney-siege-three-people-dead-including-gunman?cid= |title= Sydney siege: Gunman, two hostages dead after siege ends |work= [[Special Broadcasting Service]] |date= 16 December 2014 |accessdate= 16 December 2014}} While Monis had a warrant out for his arrest in [[Iran]], he sought political asylum in [[Australia]] in 1996, which was granted in 2001.{{cite news |url= http://www.abc.net.au/news/2014-12-16/iranian-man-haron-monis-named-as-man-behind-sydney-siege/5969246 |title= Sydney siege: Man behind Martin Place stand-off was Iranian Man Haron Monis, who had violent criminal history |publisher= Australian Broadcasting Corporation |work= ABC News |date= 16 December 2014 |first1= Lorna |last1= Knowles |accessdate= 16 December 2014}} Monis variously promoted himself as an Iranian intelligence official, a political activist, a spiritual healer and expert in [[black magic]], an [[outlaw bikie]] and a Muslim cleric. He told a psychiatrist who diagnosed him with [[schizophrenia]] that he had to change his name for "security reasons," variously calling himself "Michael Hayson Mavros",https://www.dpmc.gov.au/sites/default/files/publications/170215_Martin_Place_Siege_Review_1.pdf (p. 72) "Sheikh Haron", and "Ayatollah Mohammed Manteghi Boroujerdi".{{cite news |url= http://www.smh.com.au/nsw/martin-place-gunman-deranged-deluded-and-dangerous-20141216-128j42.html |title= Martin Place gunman deranged, deluded and dangerous |work= [[The Sydney Morning Herald]] |date= 16 December 2014 |last= Elliot |first= Tim |publisher= Fairfax Media |accessdate= 21 June 2015}} Monis ran a "spiritual healing" business, telling some women that they needed to submit to sexual molestation to receive treatment. In 2014, Monis was charged with being an accessory to the murder of his ex-wife, as well as over 40 counts of sexual assault. At the time of his death, he had recently converted from [[Shia Islam]] to [[Sunni Islam]], and attended Islamist rallies promoting conspiracy theories about Australian security agencies. While on bail, and facing a likely lengthy imprisonment, he declared allegiance to the [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant]].{{cite news |last= Safi |first= Michael |last2= Quinn |first2= Ben |url= https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2014/dec/15/man-haron-monis-sydney-siege-suspect |title= Man Haron Monis: fringe figure whose crime record and erratic behaviour made him notorious |work= [[The Guardian]] |date= 16 December 2014 |accessdate= 16 December 2014}} ==Life in Iran== Monis was born in [[Borujerd]], [[Iran]] on 19 May 1964. He published a book of poetry, ''Inside and Out'' or ''Daroon va Boroon'' ({{lang-fa|درون و برون}}), in 1996 in Iran.{{cite web |url= http://www.bbc.co.uk/persian/world/2014/12/141215_l12_sydney_shaikh_haroon |title= Who was the main suspect of the hostage? |date= 15 December 2014 |language= Persian |website= [[BBC Persian]] |publisher= British Broadcasting Corporation |accessdate= 16 December 2014}}{{cite news |url= http://theconversation.com/sydney-siege-shows-the-rise-of-a-new-form-of-extremism-35494 |title= Sydney siege shows the rise of a new form of extremism |work= [[The Conversation (website)|The Conversation]] |date= 16 December 2014 |last= Mamouri |first= Ali |accessdate= 16 December 2014}} It did not sell well, which disappointed Monis. In the 1990s, Monis ran a company called ''Salhani Amal'' ({{lang-fa|صالحان عمل}}), which he used to buy discounted tyres from the Iranian government and re-sell them on the black market. He also ran a charity scam to avoid paying tax.{{cite news|author=Paul Bibby |url=http://www.smh.com.au/nsw/lindt-cafe-siege-gunman-once-had-luxurious-life-in-tehran-funded-by-scam-involving-iranian-government-20150904-gjffaj.html |title=Lindt Cafe siege gunman once had luxurious life in Tehran funded by scam involving Iranian government |publisher=The Sydney Morning Herald |date=2015-09-04 |accessdate=2015-09-11}} In 2001, using the pseudonym Ayatollah Manteghi Boroujerdi, he claimed in an interview with [[Radio National|ABC Radio National's]] ''The Religion Report'' that he had been involved with the Iranian [[Ministry of Intelligence|ministry of intelligence and security]], and that his criticism of the regime and secret information he possessed had resulted in his persecution as well as the detention of his wife and children. During an ABC Radio interview, he claimed that his family's detention was a result of views the Iranian government believed to be "dangerously liberal". David Ruteledge, the journalist who interviewed him, described this as "a little bit dramatic." Australia granted his request for political asylum that year.{{cite web|url= https://www.bbc.com/news/world-australia-30484419|title= BBC News – Profile: Man Haron Monis|work= BBC News|accessdate= 15 December 2014}}{{cite news|author=Lucy Draper |url=http://www.newsweek.com/police-name-sydney-hostage-taker-radical-cleric-man-haron-monis-291926 |title=Police Name Sydney Hostage-Taker as 'Radical Cleric' Man Haron Monis |publisher=Newsweek.com |date=15 December 2014 |accessdate=2015-09-11}} He claimed that his request for asylum followed the detention of his wife and children by Iranian authorities after he espoused liberal views on Islam.{{cite web|url= http://www.abc.net.au/rn/religionreport/stories/2001/240626.htm|title= New Cardinals for Rome, George Bush, Muslims in Australia|work= The Religion Report|publisher= [[Radio National]]|date= 31 January 2001|accessdate= 5 April 2013}} According to London-based Persian TV channel [[Manoto 1]], he had fled Iran after taking [[United States dollar|US$]]200,000 of his customers' money in his tourism agency.{{cite web|last1= Azizi|first1= Arash|title= Exclusive: The Sydney hostage-taker had fled Iran after a $200K fraud case|url= http://manoto1.com/news/lmp7o6/NEWS16341|website= [[Manoto 1]]|accessdate= 16 December 2014}} According to [[Islamic Republic News Agency|Iran's official news agency]], he was under investigation by [[Interpol]] and [[Iranian police]] at the time he was granted asylum, and [[Australian police]] did not extradite him despite several requests. Some commentators have expressed concern regarding this immigration and citizenship process.{{cite news |url= http://www.canberratimes.com.au/comment/monis-proves-we-need-to-sort-out-our-immigration-mistakes-20141217-1297f1.html |title= Monis proves we need to sort out our immigration mistakes |author= Sheehan, Paul |date= 18 December 2014 |work= [[The Canberra Times]] |accessdate= 26 December 2014}}{{cite news |url= http://www.theaustralian.com.au/in-depth/sydney-siege/sydney-siege-man-haron-monis-flew-in-on-a-business-visa/story-fnqxbywy-1227161198324 |title= Sydney siege: Man Haron Monis flew in on a business visa |author= Bita, Natasha |date= 19 December 2014|work= [[The Australian]]|accessdate= 26 December 2014}} Esmaeil Ahmadi-Moghaddam, [[Law Enforcement Force of Islamic Republic of Iran|Iran's chief of police]], told reporters that Monis had "a dark and long history of [[violent crime]] and [[fraud]]"{{cite web |title= Iran’s Interpol ready to cooperate on Sydney case |url= http://en.mehrnews.com/detail/News/105117 |website= [[Mehr News Agency]] |date= 16 December 2014 |accessdate= 16 December 2014}} in Iran and had run a travel agency in 1996, before fleeing to [[Malaysia]] and then Australia. "It lasted 4 years to collect evidence on Manteghi [Monis]'s identification documents and we reported this to the [[Australian police]] but since Australia has no [[extradition treaty]] with Iran, they didn't extradite him to Iran". He was protected from extradition by his refugee status.{{cite web |first1= Arash |last1= Azizi |url= http://manoto1.com/news/lmp7o6/NEWS16341 |title= Exclusive: The Sydney hostage-taker had fled Iran after a $200K fraud case |work= [[Manoto 1]] |accessdate= 16 December 2014}} Iran's official [[Islamic Republic News Agency]] states that he was "under prosecution by the [[Interpol]]" and Iran provided information to the [[Australian government]] about his criminal record, mental and spiritual status. Despite this, he was granted [[right of asylum|asylum]] in Australia.{{cite web|title=Analyst derides Australian government for letting criminal do freely |url=http://www.irna.ir/en/News/81428520/ |website=[[Islamic Republic News Agency]] |date=16 December 2014 |accessdate=16 December 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150222064644/http://www.irna.ir/en/News/81428520/ |archivedate=22 February 2015 }} [[Iranian Foreign Ministry]] spokeswoman [[Marzieh Afkham]] publicly questioned the decisions made by the Australian government after several discussions in which Monis's criminal status in Iran was made "completely clear". ==Life in Australia== He migrated to Australia as a refugee in 1996 seeking [[political asylum]].{{cite news |title= Man Haron Monis' legal history |url= http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/latest-news/man-haron-monis-legal-history/story-fn3dxiwe-1227158650122 |work= The Australian |date= 16 December 2014 |quote= BORN: May 19, 1964 in Iran and arrived in Australia as a refugee in 1996. |accessdate= 18 December 2014}} He used a one-month business visa to gain entry to the country. He applied for a protection visa when his business visa expired, and was granted a bridging visa while the protection visa application was assessed.https://www.dpmc.gov.au/sites/default/files/publications/170215_Martin_Place_Siege_Review_1.pdf (p. 21) From 1997 to 2000, Monis held a security guard licence, which would have let him carry a pistol between March and June 1997.https://www.dpmc.gov.au/sites/default/files/publications/170215_Martin_Place_Siege_Review_1.pdf (p. 45) In November 2000, he chained himself to a pole at [[Parliament House, Sydney]], and went on a one-day hunger strike to draw attention to his cause.{{cite news |title= Heat Puts Paid To Iran Cleric's Hunger Strike |work= The West Australian |author= Ruse, Ben |quote= Armed with just a sleeping bag and some bottled water, Iranian immigrant Ayatollah Manteghi Boroujerdi had chained himself to a pole yesterday afternoon. He hoped the protest would convince the Iranian Government to let him see his two daughters for the first time in four years. |date= 23 November 2000}}{{cite news |title= The mystery mufti is no great sheik --- Australians at war |work= The Daily Telegraph |date= 22 October 2009 |author= Fife-Yeomans, Janet |quote= As Ayatollah Manteghi Boroujerdi, the tall, bearded Iranian chained himself to the railings outside the NSW Parliament in Macquarie St where he lived in a tent for several weeks in a bid to persuade the Federal Government to put pressure on Iran to let his family join him in Australia. |publisher= News Limited}} He began to sexually assault women while passing himself off as a spiritual healer named 'Marcus' in the early 2000s.{{cite news|title=How authorities underestimated siege gunman Monis|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2017-05-22/lindt-cafe-sydney-siege-gunman-man-haron-monis/8375858|accessdate=23 May 2017|work=ABC News|date=22 May 2017|language=en-AU}} On 16 September 2002, Monis changed his name to Michael Hayson Mavros. While he was known as Mavros, he seemed to be 'embracing a secular life'.https://www.dpmc.gov.au/sites/default/files/publications/170215_Martin_Place_Siege_Review_1.pdf (p. 15) He gained Australian citizenship in 2004. On 21 September 2006, he changed his name to Man Haron Monis.[https://www.dpmc.gov.au/sites/default/files/publications/170215_Martin_Place_Siege_Review_1.pdf Martin Place Siege Review] (p. 72) PDF www.dpmc.gov.au Monis was investigated by the [[Australian Security Intelligence Organisation]] four times, and there were more than 40 calls to ASIO's [[National Security Hotline (Australia)|National Security Hotline]].{{cite web|url= http://www.abc.net.au/7.30/content/2015/s4242253.htm|title= Sydney siege inquest builds picture of Man Haron Monis' 'bizarre, delusional' world|work= [[7.30]]|date= 25 May 2015}} The family of his partner called the National Security Hotline in 2010 and were advised Monis "wasn't a threat". Monis had been on the [[Australian Security Intelligence Organisation]]'s watch-list in 2008 and 2009, but was dropped off the list for reasons that were not specified.{{cite web|url= https://news.yahoo.com/australia-pm-lays-flowers-memorials-victims-051949987.html|title= Aussie leader: Siege gunman dropped off watch list|date= 16 December 2014|work= Yahoo News|accessdate= 17 December 2014}} In 2009, in [[Granville, New South Wales|Granville, NSW]], Monis gave a lecture calling for an Islamic society and taunting foreign governments saying, "your intelligence service is not working properly."{{cite news |url= http://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/news/nsw/taped-granville-lectures-give-glimpse-inside-the-crazed-mind-of-sydney-terrorist-man-haron-monis/story-fni0cx12-1227172184191 |title= Taped Granville lectures give glimpse inside the crazed mind of Sydney terrorist Man Haron Monis |author= Auerbach, Taylor |date= 2 January 2015 |work= [[The Daily Telegraph]] |accessdate= 2 January 2015}} Monis lived in a flat with a housemate for six months in 1998. Monis said he was a senior member of the clergy in Iran, always locked his bedroom door, even when he went to the bathroom, and told his housemate not to bring friends over and not to answer the door if anyone knocked.{{cite web|url= http://www.abc.net.au/news/2015-06-03/monis-borrowed-money-from-flatmate/6517838|title= Sydney siege inquest: Family of Man Haron Monis's girlfriend reported him to the National Security Hotline|work= ABC News|date= 3 June 2015}} Monis said that he was in "financial hardship" and borrowed payments amounting to $9,000 - which were never repaid. ===Spouses=== In 2003, Monis dated Amanda Morsy for about six months, telling her he was Romanian, giving her gold necklaces and driving her to dates in a [[Mercedes-Benz|Mercedes]], convertible [[Peugeot]] and a [[Jeep]]. Monis was unable to be contacted after 8 pm, claiming he was busy with his "spiritual consultation" business. Morsy described him as "secretive", "very reserved" and "formal" and wanting to "fit in" - and broke the relationship off after her family expresses reservations about his personality. In 2003, Monis married a woman who was a client of his black magic business, though always kept his blinds closed, and told people at a Sydney mosque that he had a wife in Iran. In July 2011, Monis was charged at a [[St Marys, New South Wales|St Mary's]] police station for intimidation of his ex-wife, following a confrontation in a [[McDonald's]] car park in [[Green Valley, New South Wales|Green Valley]].{{cite news |author= Mazoe Ford |url= http://www.abc.net.au/news/2014-12-17/sydney-siege-man-haron-monis-ex-partner-feared-shooting/5973236 |title= Sydney siege: Man Haron Monis's ex-partner Noleen Hayson Pal feared he would shoot her |publisher= Australian Broadcasting Corporation |work= ABC News |date= 17 December 2014 |accessdate= 18 December 2014}} His ex-wife claimed Monis had threatened to shoot her and told her that he held a gun licence. In 2010, the family of Amirah Droudis reported Monis to the National Security Hotline because they found his behaviour strange. He was secretive with the family and always refused to have his photo taken even at Christmas. He gave them the appearance of having money and being "very generous" but vague about where he worked. They described him as "rarely forthcoming with any direct or detailed answers." Social worker Sylvia Martin talked with Monis during a meeting with his former wife in 2012. She described Monis as prone to "[[grandiosity]]" and a "hero in his own story" describing him as "capable of [[narcissism]] and also capable of [[Psychological manipulation|manipulation]]." His ex-wife said that Monis had "intimidated, duped and emotionally manipulated her" and that around 2007 he "became more strict" and told her to wear a veil, and restricted her from "singing and dancing" allegedly telling her "I'm doing it for Islam ... I want to be a martyr".{{cite web|url= http://www.smh.com.au/nsw/lindt-cafe-siege-gunman-man-haron-monis-wanted-to-be-a-hero-in-his-own-story-inquest-hears-20150601-ghdyh9.html|title= Lindt Cafe siege: Gunman Man Haron Monis wanted to be 'a hero in his own story', inquest hears|work= The Sydney Morning Herald|date= 1 June 2015}} ====Accessory to murder charge==== On 21 April 2013, Monis' ex-wife's body was found stabbed 17 times and alight in a [[Werrington, New South Wales|Werrington]] apartment stairwell. Monis' girlfriend Amirah Droudis was formally charged with murder, and on 15 November 2013, Monis was charged by [[NSW Police]] with being an [[accessory before the fact]] and an [[accessory after the fact]] to the murder.{{cite news |url= http://www.abc.net.au/news/2013-11-22/self-styled-muslim-sheikh-faces-court-on-accessory-to-murder-ch/5111744 |title= Self-styled Muslim sheikh faces court on accessory to murder charge |publisher= Australian Broadcasting Corporation |work= ABC News |date= 22 November 2013 |agency= AAP |accessdate= 8 February 2014}} On 12 December 2013, Monis and Amirah appeared before [[Magistrate]] William Pierce at [[Penrith, New South Wales|Penrith]] Local Court where they were granted bail.12 December 2013 court list Penrith Magistrate Court The magistrate said there were significant flaws in the Crown's case against the pair and that "It is a weak case".{{cite news |url= http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/nation/murder-case-against-man-haron-monis-and-partner-weak-magistrate/story-e6frg6nf-1226781538379 |title= Murder case against Man Haron Monis and partner weak: magistrate |publisher= News Limited |work= The Australian |date= 12 December 2013 |agency= AAP |accessdate= 8 February 2014}} Prosecutor Brian Royce said Monis' claims that the [[Ministry of Intelligence and National Security (Iran)|Iranian Secret Police]] and the [[Australian Security Intelligence Organisation]] (ASIO) were trying to frame him for the murder were fanciful. Magistrate Pierce said all theories needed to be examined.{{cite news |date= 13 December 2013 |title= Hate sheikh Man Haron Monis and girlfriend Amirah Droudis granted bail on murder charges |url= http://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/news/nsw/hate-sheik-man-horan-monis-and-girlfriend-amirzh-droudis-granted-bail-on-murder-charges/story-fni0cx12-1226781623998 |work= The Daily Telegraph |publisher= News Corp |accessdate= 21 June 2015}} On 22 January 2014, Monis appeared at [[Parramatta, New South Wales|Parramatta]] Local Court and, after informing magistrate Joan Baptie that he was representing himself, began discussing documents that he claimed were held by ASIO. He also claimed that ASIO was "conspiring against him" as they wanted him jailed. Magistrate Baptie told Monis that she had no power to order the release of documents held by ASIO and "advised him to stop talking because he would harm his defence". Monis staged a protest outside the court, following the adjournment of the case, "wearing chains and holding a sign claiming he has been tortured in custody". He was quoted as saying: "This is not a criminal case. This is a political case."{{cite news |url= http://www.abc.net.au/news/2014-01-22/controversial-sheik-haron-faces-accessory-to-ex-wife27s-murder/5212862 |title= Controversial Sheikh Haron faces accessory to ex-wife's murder charge |publisher= [[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]] |work= ABC News |date= 22 January 2014 |last= McNally |first= Lucy |accessdate= 16 December 2014}} ===Claims of membership of Iranian Intelligence=== Monis told individuals in Australia, including his lawyers, that he had worked for the [[Iranian Ministry of Intelligence and Security]] and had knowledge about Iran's clandestine operations, and that it was for this reason he fled Iran.{{cite web|url= http://www.smh.com.au/nsw/martin-place-gunman-man-haron-moniss-secret-iranian-life-20141222-12c9ny.html|title= Martin Place gunman Man Haron Monis's secret Iranian life|work= The Sydney Morning Herald}} However, an Iranian embassy official stated Monis' claim to have worked in intelligence and security in Iran was a lie.http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/features/sydney-siege-inside-the-mind-of-cbd-terrorist-man-haron-monis/story-e6frg6z6-1227162502613 {{Subscription required|date=September 2015}} Monis said he was the secretary of the Iranian intelligence department.{{cite news |url= http://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/news/nsw/spy-lies-that-opened-the-door-to-mad-lindt-cafe-killer-man-haron-monis/story-fnpn118l-1227175339775 |title= ‘Spy’ lies that opened the door to mad Lindt cafe killer Man Haron Monis |first1= Taylor |last1= Auerbach |first2= Paul |last2= Toohey |date= 6 January 2015 |work= [[Daily Telegraph]] |accessdate= 6 January 2015}} After 9/11, Monis called ASIO saying he knew Iran was responsible and asked for a financial reward for the information. He also asked ASIO to pay him to work as an informant.{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/pm/content/2015/s4354820.htm|title=PM - Security hotline received warnings about Man Monis days before Lindt Cafe siege 18/11/2015|publisher=}} ===Allegations of fabricated cleric status=== Monis proclaimed himself to be a [[Akhoond|Shia cleric]].{{cite news |url= https://www.bbc.com/news/world-australia-30484419 |title= Man Haron Monis: 'Damaged' and 'unstable' |work= [[BBC]] |date= 16 December 2014 |publisher= British Broadcasting Corporation |accessdate= 16 December 2014}}{{cite episode |title= New Cardinals for Rome, George Bush, Muslims in Australia |series= The Religion Report |credits= Presenter: Stephen Crittenden |network= Radio National |airdate= 31 January 2001 |transcript= Transcript |transcripturl= http://www.abc.net.au/radionational/programs/religionreport/new-cardinals-for-rome-george-bush-muslims-in/3478556#transcript}} In late 2007, [[Australian Federation of Islamic Councils]] head Ikebal Patel said no Islamic community leaders knew anything about Monis and believed he "could be a fake deliberately stirring up [[Islamophobia|anti-Islamic sentiment]]".{{cite web |url= http://www.theaustralian.com.au/national-affairs/defence/sheik-faked-to-stir-up-ill-feeling/story-e6frg8yo-1111115203676 |title= Sheik 'faked' to stir up ill-feeling |publisher= News Limited |work= [[The Australian]] |date= 28 December 2007 |last= Kerbaj |first= Richard |accessdate= 16 December 2014}} On 28 January 2008, Australia's senior Shia leader and head of [[Islamic organisations in Australia|Supreme Islamic Shia Council of Australia]], Kamal Mousselmani, told ''[[The Australian]]'' that Monis "was not a genuine Shia spiritual leader" and "there are no [[ayatollah]]s in Australia." He urged Federal government officials to investigate his identity. "From the way he writes his [[fatwa]]s (or religious edicts), I don't think he is [[Shia Muslim]]", he added.{{cite web |url= http://www.theaustralian.com.au/national-affairs/defence/call-to-probe-mystery-shia-cleric/story-e6frg8yx-1111115413357 |title= Call to probe mystery Shia cleric |publisher= News Limited |work= [[The Australian]] |date= 28 January 2008 |last= Kerbaj |first= Richard |accessdate= 16 December 2014}} ===Psychiatric assessment=== In 2010 Monis was [[emergency psychiatry|involuntarily hospitalised]] at [[Canterbury Hospital]] after displaying bizarre and erratic behaviour in a parking lot in [[Ashfield, New South Wales|Ashfield]]. A psychiatrist who assessed Monis said she believed he had chronic schizophrenia and needed to be on anti-psychotic medication. Monis stated that he had been forced to close his spiritual business, was $20,000 in debt, and had to change his name for "security reasons."{{cite web|url= http://www.abc.net.au/news/2015-05-27/sydney-siege-inquest-man-haron-monis-schizophrenia-bail/6499862|title= Sydney siege inquest: Prosecutors move to stop inquiry considering Man Haron Monis's bail freedom|work= ABC News|date= 27 May 2015}} Monis was treated by two different psychiatrists who didn't know about the other and he was giving them different information.{{cite web|url= http://www.abc.net.au/news/2015-05-28/sydney-siege-inquest-man-monis-thought-people-read-his-mind/6502890|title= Sydney siege inquest: Man Haron Monis thought 'people could read his mind', inquiry told|work= ABC News|date= 28 May 2015}} He was described as "quite guarded and reluctant to disclose too much information" and refused to give his phone number and home address. He was concerned that "ASIO and police were following him... and that some people could read his mind," according to a psychologist who grew up in Iran, who diagnosed him with [[Obsessive–compulsive disorder|obsessive-compulsive disorder]]. He avoided buying medication for mental illness with his [[Medicare (Australia)|Medicare]] card to conceal his use of medication from authorities. One solicitor said that Monis seemed paranoid and would often speak with his hand over his mouth because he thought people "watching him" might be able to lip read.{{cite web|url= http://www.abc.net.au/news/2015-06-01/sydney-siege-gunman-monis-wanted-to-be-hero-in-his-own-story/6510702|title= Sydney siege inquest: Man Haron Monis wanted to be 'hero in his own story'|work= ABC News|date= 1 June 2015}} ===Hate mail campaign=== Monis, together with Amirah Droudis, undertook a campaign protesting against the presence of Australian troops in [[War in Afghanistan (2001–present)|Afghanistan]], by writing letters to the families of soldiers killed there, in which he called the soldiers murderers,{{cite news |url= http://www.sbs.com.au/news/article/2013/09/06/sheik-says-letters-were-flowers-advice |title= Sheik says letters were flowers of advice |publisher= Special Broadcasting Service |work= SBS News |date= 6 September 2013 |author= Staff |accessdate= 8 February 2014}} and urged the soldiers' families to petition the government to remove its troops from Afghanistan. According to Justice [[Dyson Heydon]] of the High Court, the letters compared "the (deceased soldier) son to a pig and to a dirty animal. It calls the son's body 'contaminated'. It refers to it as 'the dirty body of a pig'. It describes Hitler as not inferior to the son in moral merit".{{cite web |last= Mason |first= David |url= https://www.humanrights.gov.au/publications/casenote-monis-v-queen-2013-hca-4-1|title= Casenote: Monis v The Queen [2013] HCA 4|publisher= [[Australian Human Rights Commission]] - www.humanrights.gov.au |date= 6 March 2013 |format = PDF and Word |accessdate= 15 December 2014}} Monis was arrested on charges of "using a postal or similar service to menace, harass or cause offence".{{cite news |url= http://www.abc.net.au/lateline/content/2008/s2739013.htm |title= 'Hate mail' suspect protests against 'misinterpretation' |publisher= Australian Broadcasting Corporation |work= [[Lateline]] |date= 22 November 2013 |last= Hoerr |first= Karl |accessdate= 8 February 2014}} Droudis received a 2-year good-behaviour bond for "assisting Monis in sending the letters". She appealed the sentence, but on 12 March 2015 Droudis dropped her appeal.{{cite news |last1= Dale|first1= Amy |title= Amirah Droudis drops bid to overturn offensive letters conviction |url= http://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/news/nsw/amirah-droudis-drops-bid-to-overturn-offensive-letters-conviction/story-fni0cx12-1227259793237 |work= The Daily Telegraph |publisher= News Corp|date= 12 March 2015 |accessdate= 13 March 2015}} ===Court cases=== {{main|Monis v The Queen}} On 10 November 2009, Monis appeared in court and claimed through his lawyers to be a peace activist. He later chained himself to the courthouse in protest over the charges.{{cite news |url= http://www.sbs.com.au/news/article/2009/11/10/controversial-sheik-chains-outside-court |title= Controversial Sheik in chains outside court |publisher= Special Broadcasting Service |work= SBS News |date= 10 November 2009 |agency= AAP |accessdate= 8 February 2014}} Monis was subsequently barred by the courts from expanding his protest to include letters to [[UK]] soldiers' families.{{cite news |url= http://www.sbs.com.au/news/article/2010/02/09/sheik-banned-sending-offensive-mail |title= Sheik banned from sending offensive mail |publisher= Special Broadcasting Service |work= SBS News |date= 9 February 2010 |agency= AAP |accessdate= 8 February 2014}} In an inquest, lawyer Chris Murphy said that Monis claimed to be contacting families to recruit "people who had suffered loss in war" to join his cause. Murphy said "He didn't strike me as very intelligent." Monis chained himself to the courthouse against the directions of lawyers, and Murphy said "He was entirely self absorbed with his performance ... my recollection is he held a pen in the air and said 'this is my sword'." Lawyers described Monis as a "pest" and a "dickhead".{{cite web|url= http://www.abc.net.au/news/2015-05-29/lindt-cafe-siege-man-haron-monis-lawyers-give-evidence/6506312|title= Sydney siege inquest: Lawyer says Man Haron Monis was a pest and not very intelligent|work= ABC News|date= 29 May 2015}} Manny Conditsis said that conversations with Monis were "draining and exhausting." Monis expressed conspiracy theories about ASIO, claiming that families of dead soldiers were not upset at his letters, but "ASIO was putting them up to it." He said "Monis was a very proud man," who cried "like a baby" in prison. Another lawyer said he always wanted to be "the centre of attention" in the media. In December 2011, Monis appeared before the [[Court of Criminal Appeal]] in Sydney arguing that the charges against him were invalid because they infringed his implied constitutional freedom of political communication, but the three-judge panel unanimously dismissed his case.{{cite news |url= http://www.abc.net.au/news/2011-12-06/cleric-loses-appeal-over-dead-soldier-hate-mail/3715612 |title= Cleric loses appeal over dead soldier hate mail |publisher= Australian Broadcasting Corporation |work= ABC News |date= 6 December 2011 |agency= AAP |accessdate= 8 February 2014}} Upon further appeal to the [[High Court of Australia]], the six-judge panel split 3–3 over the issue.{{cite news |url= http://www.abc.net.au/radionational/programs/lawreport/rundle-street-preachers/4548266#transcript |title= High court divided on freedom of speech |publisher= Australian Broadcasting Corporation |work= Law Report |date= 5 March 2013 |last= Carrick |first= Damien |network= Radio National |accessdate= 8 February 2014}} Although the [[High Court of Australia]] normally comprises seven judges, one seat was vacant and as yet unfilled at the time Monis's case appeared before the court. Failing to achieve a majority vote in Monis's favour, the lower court's unanimous decision was left to stand.{{cite news |url= http://www.abc.net.au/news/2013-02-27/high-court-decision/4542482 |title= High Court dismisses appeal over letters to dead soldiers' families |publisher= Australian Broadcasting Corporation |work= ABC News |date= 27 February 2013 |last= Byrne |first= Elizabeth |accessdate= 8 February 2014}} On 12 December 2014, Monis' [[appeal]] against his conviction for criminal use of the postal service resulted in a split decision of the High Court.{{cite web |url= http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/12/15/sydney-hostage-crisis_n_6327220.html |title= Sydney Hostage Crisis Over After Police Storm Cafe |work= The Huffington Post |accessdate= 15 December 2014}} The decision related to his protest against the presence of Australian troops in [[War in Afghanistan (2001–present)|Afghanistan]], which he expressed by sending letters to the families of soldiers killed there in which he called the soldiers murderers{{cite news |author= AAP|date= 6 September 2013|title= Sheik says letters were flowers of advice |url= http://www.sbs.com.au/news/article/2013/09/06/sheik-says-letters-were-flowers-advice |work= SBS News |publisher= sbs.com.au |accessdate= 8 February 2014}} and urged the families to petition the government to remove its troops from Afghanistan. One of the letters compared a dead soldier to a pig and called his body "contaminated".{{cite web|url= https://www.humanrights.gov.au/publications/casenote-monis-v-queen-2013-hca-4-1|title= Casenote: Monis v The Queen [2013] HCA 4|work= humanrights.gov.au|accessdate= 15 December 2014}} He sent similar letters to the families of British soldiers and the mother{{cite web|url= https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/australiaandthepacific/australia/11294514/Sydney-siege-gunman-named-as-Man-Haron-Monis.html|title= Sydney siege gunman named as Man Haron Monis|author= Jonathan Pearlman in Sydney|date= 15 December 2014|work= Telegraph.co.uk|accessdate= 15 December 2014}} of a government official killed by a bombing in [[Jakarta]], Indonesia. Monis pleaded guilty and was sentenced to probation and 300 hours of [[community service]] and banned from using the [[Australia Post|Australian postal service]].{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/12/16/world/asia/sydney-australia-hostages.html|title=Sydney Hostage Siege Ends With Gunman and 2 Captives Dead as Police Storm Cafe|date=16 December 2014|work=The New York Times}}{{cite web|url= https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/world/wp/2014/12/15/before-he-took-hostages-at-a-sydney-cafe-man-haron-monis-had-been-tied-to-alleged-murder-sexual-assaults-and-offensive-letters/|title= Before the Sydney siege, alleged gunman Man Haron Monis faced sexual assault, murder conspiracy charges|work= Washington Post|accessdate= 15 December 2014}}{{cite news |last= Hoerr |first= Karl |date= 22 November 2013 |title= 'Hate mail' suspect protests against 'misinterpretation' |url= http://www.abc.net.au/lateline/content/2008/s2739013.htm |work= Lateline |publisher= abc.net.au |accessdate= 8 February 2014}} According to ''[[The Age]]'', this conviction consumed him for several years, and the hostage incident followed three days after an unsuccessful attempt to have the conviction overturned.{{cite news |url= http://www.theage.com.au/nsw/sydney-siege-gunman-man-haron-monis-was-on-bail-for-40-sexual-assault-charges-and-accessory-to-murder-20141215-127u1e.html |title= Sydney siege gunman Man Haron Monis was on bail for 40 sexual assault charges and accessory to murder |newspaper= The Age}} Monis had been granted conditional bail because the magistrate said "there were significant flaws in the Crown's case".{{cite news |last1= Louise Hall, Paul Bibby |title= Sydney siege gunman Man Haron Monis was on bail for 40 sexual assault charges and accessory to murder |url= http://www.smh.com.au/nsw/sydney-siege-gunman-man-haron-monis-was-on-bail-for-40-sexual-assault-charges-and-accessory-to-murder-20141215-127u1e.html |work= The Sydney Morning Herald|date= 16 December 2014 |accessdate= 18 December 2014}} ===Rebels Motorcycle Club=== Monis attempted to join the [[Rebels Motorcycle Club]] sometime in 2012 or 2013, and was photographed with a "1%" logo representing [[outlaw motorcycle club]]s. Club members reportedly stated "no one really liked him" and described him as "strange and weird" and said "He would say he had a lot of money, but then he didn't have any." He was kicked out of the club and Rebels took his motorbike.{{cite web|url= http://www.smh.com.au/nsw/lindt-cafe-siege-inquest-man-haron-monis-wanted-to-be-a-rebels-bikie-20150525-gh93k4.html|title= Lindt cafe siege inquest: Man Haron Monis wanted to be a Rebels bikie|work= The Sydney Morning Herald|date= 25 May 2015}}{{cite web|url= http://www.abc.net.au/news/2015-05-25/sydney-siege-inquest-man-monis-lindt-cafe-martin-place/6493752|title= Sydney siege inquest: Hostage taker Man Haron Monis tried to join Rebels bikie gang, rejected as 'weird'|date= 25 May 2015|publisher= Australian Broadcasting Corporation}} ===Sexual assault charges=== Monis ran a "spiritual healing" business and promoted himself as a clairvoyant an expert in "astrology, numerology, meditation and black magic" services.{{cite news |url= http://www.abc.net.au/news/2014-04-14/spiritual-healer-arrested-for-sexual-assault/5388332 |title= 'Spiritual healer' refused bail over alleged 2002 sexual assaults at Wentworthville in Sydney's west |publisher= Australian Broadcasting Corporation |work= ABC News |date= 14 April 2014 |accessdate= 14 April 2014}} The business has been described as a front for sexual advances on vulnerable women, who were told that they could only receive treatment if they were undressed and massaged on the breasts and genitals. With some women, he threatened black magic curses if they did not submit to sex with him. On 14 March 2014, Monis was arrested and charged with sexually and indecently assaulting a young woman who went to his consultancy in [[Wentworthville, New South Wales]], for "spiritual healing", after seeing an advertisement in a local newspaper. Seven months later, on 13 October 2014, a further 40 charges were added, including 22 counts of aggravated sexual assault and 14 counts of aggravated indecent assault, allegedly committed against six more women who had visited his business.{{cite news |url= http://www.skynews.com.au/news/local/sydney/2014/10/13/40-more-charges-against--spiritual-healer-.html |title= 40 more charges against 'spiritual healer' |work= [[Sky News Australia]] |date= 13 October 2014 |accessdate= 16 December 2014}} ===Political activity=== Monis promoted himself as a [[peace activist]], and told his lawyers that his [[hate-mail]] campaign was to make families of dead soldiers support peace. Commercial news media in Sydney often condemned Monis for making videos with his girlfriend narrating, expressing happiness about the [[Holocaust]] and [[9/11]] and attacking rape victims.{{cite web|url= http://www.news.com.au/national/nsw-act/amirah-droudis-girlfriend-of-gunman-man-haron-monis-appears-in-vile-youtube-videos/story-fnj3rq0y-1227158281328|title= Amirah Droudis, girlfriend of gunman Man Haron Monis, appears in vile YouTube videos|work= news.com.au|date= 16 December 2014}} Monis hated [[Seven Network|Channel Seven]] for their coverage of the [[Muhamed Haneef]] affair,{{cite web|url= http://www.smh.com.au/nsw/sydney-siege-man-monis-claimed-sunrise-host-david-koch-was-a-killer-and-a-terrorist-20150602-gher8n.html|title= Sydney siege: Man Monis claimed Sunrise host David Koch was 'a killer and a terrorist'|author= Louise Hall|date= 3 June 2015}} and ran aggressive protests outside their studios. He once rushed at television hosts [[Melissa Doyle]] and [[David Koch (television presenter)|David Koch]] in [[Martin Place]] yelling, "You are a killer and a terrorist." Monis would often put on clerical garb and chain himself to a post visible from the Channel Seven live studio, handing out pamphlets declaring there was a "[[War on Islam]]" - leading the network to move studios when broadcasting the Sunrise program.{{cite web|url= https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2015/jun/02/sydney-siege-inquest-gunman-accused-tv-hosts-of-being-killers-and-terrorists|title= Sydney siege inquest: gunman accused TV hosts of being 'killers and terrorists'|work= The Guardian|date= 2 June 2015}} Following the [[Haneef]] affair, in which a doctor was accused of aiding terrorists, Monis handed out pamphlets against Sunrise alleging that they told "Muslim doctors" that "If you want to kill people, why not use the tools of your own trade like a plague or a disease or something?" Monis made complaints to Channel Seven and the [[Australian Communications and Media Authority]], which were dismissed. [[Kevin Rudd]] publicised his consideration of changes to citizenship laws during the prosecution of Monis's letters.{{cite web|url= http://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/kevin-rudd-outraged-at-sheiks-letters/story-e6freuy9-1225790202274|title= Kevin Rudd outraged at sheik's letters|date= 23 October 2009|work= Daily Telegraph}}{{cite web|url= http://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/kevin-rudd-to-ponder-citizenship-laws-as-sheik-haron-accused-of-harassing-dead-digger-families/story-e6freuy9-1225789920643|title= Kevin Rudd to ponder citizenship laws as Sheik Haron accused of harassing dead Digger families|work= Daily Telegraph|date= 22 October 2009}} Monis used social media to attack politicians including then Australian Prime Minister [[Tony Abbott]] and former Prime Minister [[Kevin Rudd]]. His criticisms of Abbott, from 2013, related to Australia's military presence in Afghanistan. On 5 December 2014, he referred to a statement made by Rudd on changing immigration laws after Monis had been charged with seven counts of harassment. Before it was taken down, on 15 December 2014, Monis's [[Facebook]] account had 14,000 "[[like button|likes]]".{{cite news |url= http://www.theage.com.au/federal-politics/political-news/martin-place-siege-man-haron-monis-has-long-history-of-hatred-of-politicians-20141215-127t01.html |title= Martin Place siege: Man Haron Monis has long history of hatred of politicians |work= [[The Age]] |date= 16 December 2014 |last= Wroe |first= David |last2= Massola |first2= James |last3= Aston |first3= Heath |publisher= Fairfax Media |accessdate= 16 December 2014}} Monis featured a photograph of [[Osama bin Laden]] on his website in 2008. It has been reported that Monis was radicalised by members of [[Hizb ut-Tahrir#Australia|Hizb ut-Tahrir]].{{cite news |url= http://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/news/nsw/martin-place-terrorist-man-haron-moniss-links-with-extremist-group-hizb-ut-tahrir-revealed/story-fni0cx12-1227172138089 |title= Martin Place terrorist Man Haron Monis’s links with extremist group Hizb ut-Tahrir revealed |author= Auerbach, Taylor |date= 2 January 2015 |work= [[The Daily Telegraph]] |accessdate= 2 January 2015}} In June 2014 Monis attended a presentation by Uthman Badar and [[Wassim Doureihi]] of Hizb ut-Tahrir which was held in response to an earlier Uthman Badar lecture titled 'Honour Killings are Morally Justified', which was cancelled.{{cite news|url=http://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/news/nsw/lindt-cafe-gunman-man-haron-monis-was-honoured-guest-at-hizb-ut-tahrirs-lakemba-hate-fest/story-fnpn118l-1227265393578 |title=Lindt cafe gunman Man Haron Monis was honoured guest at Hizb ut-Tahrir’s Lakemba hate-fest |publisher=The Daily Telegraph |date=17 March 2015 |accessdate=2015-09-11}} Monis attended Hizb ut-Tahrir rallies and was described by ''Sydney Morning Herald'' journalist Anne Davies as "a little unstable. He also seemed a little creepy. Ominously, he also told me he did not think giving speeches would be enough."{{cite web|url= http://www.smh.com.au/nsw/sydney-siege-ends-a-reporters-encounter-with-man-haron-monis-20141216-12832j.html|title= Sydney siege ends: A reporter's encounter with Man Haron Monis|date= 16 December 2014|work= The Sydney Morning Herald}} ====Seeking contact with ISIS==== In October 2014, Monis wrote a letter to [[George Brandis]]' office seeking advice on the legality of communicating with ISIS.{{cite web|url= http://www.abc.net.au/news/2015-05-28/sydney-siege-man-monis-letter-not-threatening-george-brandis/6502582|title= Sydney siege: A-G George Brandis asked why letter from Man Haron Monis did not trigger alarm bells|work= ABC News}} ====Conversion to Sunni Islam==== Monis claimed to have converted from [[Shia Islam]] to [[Sunni Islam]].[http://nymag.com/daily/intelligencer/2014/12/what-we-know-about-the-sydney-hostage-taker.html Everything We Know Now About the Sydney Hostage-Taker], nymag.com; accessed 16 December 2014. An announcement on his now-suspended website, posted a week before the Sydney siege, stated: "I used to be a [[Rafidi]], but not any more. Now I am a Muslim, [[Alhamdulillah|Alhamdu Lillah]]."{{cite news |url= http://www.channel4.com/news/who-is-sydney-gunman-man-haron-monis |title= Who was Sydney gunman Man Haron Monis? |work= [[Channel 4]] |date= 15 December 2014 |accessdate= 16 December 2014}} "[[Rafidi]]", which means "one who rejects" in Arabic, "is typically used by Sunnis to denigrate Shias as non-Muslim."{{cite news |url= http://www.theaustralian.com.au/in-depth/gunman-man-haron-monis-was-damaged-self-styled-muslim-cleric/story-fnqxbywy-1227157547335 |title= Gunman Man Haron Monis was ‘damaged’ self-styled Muslim cleric |work= [[The Australian]] |date= 15 December 2014 |last= Berkovic |first= Nicola |last2= Klan |first2= Anthony |publisher= News Limited |accessdate= 16 December 2014}} Monis also used his website to pledge allegiance to [[Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi]], leader of the Islamic State whose 'main enemies' are the Shi'a. On the day prior to taking a group of people hostage, Monis posted to his website: {{blockquote|Islam is the religion of peace, that's why Muslims fight against the oppression and terrorism of USA and its allies including UK and Australia. If we stay silent towards the criminals we cannot have a peaceful society. The more you fight with crime, the more peaceful you are. Islam wants peace on the Earth, that's why Muslims want to stop terrorism of America and its allies. When you speak out against crime you have taken one step towards peace.}} [[Australian Muslim]] commentators said that his [[religious conversion|conversion]] to Sunni Islam was less out of genuine religious conviction than designed to provide credibility in seeking an association with ISIL, as one "can't really claim to love IS when you're a Shiite and they're trying to exterminate you".{{cite news |last1= Aly |first1= Waleed |title= Sydney gunman Man Haron Monis a real sheikh only to himself |url= http://www.smh.com.au/comment/sydney-gunman-man-haron-monis-a-real-sheikh-only-to-himself-20141216-128h9x.html |work= The Sydney Morning Herald |date= 17 December 2014 |accessdate= 17 December 2014}} He was a long-time self-proclaimed [[sheikh]], albeit not recognised as such in the Islamic community.{{cite news |last1= Knowles|first1= Lorna |title= Sydney siege: Man behind siege named as Iranian cleric Man Haron Monis |url= http://www.abc.net.au/news/2014-12-16/cleric/5969246 |work= ABC News |date= 16 December 2014 |accessdate= 15 December 2014}} He was marginalised by [[Islam in Australia|Australian Muslim]] religious authorities and mosques for his extremist views and problematic personal and criminal history. It appears he came to espouse an [[Islamic extremism|extreme Islamist ideology]] on his own, and police and intelligence agencies have not identified any connections between Monis and international [[terrorist organisations]].{{cite web|url= http://www.cbsnews.com/news/sydney-hostages-police-raid-downtown-cafe/|title= Sydney hostage crisis ends; gunman dead after raid|date= 15 December 2014|publisher= |accessdate= 15 December 2014}} ==The Lindt Cafe Siege== {{main|2014 Sydney hostage crisis}} [[File:Chalk messages, Martin Place.JPG|thumb|Messages chalked on [[Martin Place, Sydney|Martin Place]] after the event]] On the morning of 15 December 2014, Monis took hostage employees and customers at the [[Lindt & Sprüngli|Lindt]] chocolate café in [[Martin Place, Sydney]], across from a [[Seven Network]] television studio. Hostages were made to hold up a [[Jihadist black flag|Black Standard]] with the ''[[shahada|shahādah]]'' (Islamic statement of faith) written in white Arabic text.{{cite web |url= http://www.news.com.au/national/breaking-news/seven-evacuates-newsroom-near-cafe-siege/story-e6frfku9-1227156337550 |title= Seven in 'lockdown' due to hostage crisis |publisher= News Limited |work= news.com.au |accessdate= 15 December 2014}} Neighbouring buildings, including government offices and financial institutions, and [[Martin Place railway station]], were evacuated and locked down. Some hostages managed to escape. The event lasted over 16 hours when hostages made a run for the exit with Monis firing missing all hostages. Monis then took Tori Johnston (the cafe manager) at gunpoint forcing him to kneel before firing a fatal shot into Johnston's head. [[State Protection Group|Police tactical officers]] then decided to storm the café resulting in a shootout between Monis and police in the early hours of the following morning{{cite news |first1= Daniel |last1= Franklin |url= http://livenews.abc.net.au/Event/Live_blog_Siege_in_Sydneys_Martin_Place/137083674 |title= Live blog: Siege in Sydney's Martin Place |publisher= Australian Broadcasting Corporation |work= ABC News |date= 15 December 2014 |accessdate= 15 December 2014}}{{cite web |url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-australia-30485355 |title= Sydney cafe siege: Australia police storm building |publisher= British Broadcasting Corporation |work= BBC News |date= 15 December 2014}} and Monis was confirmed by police to have died in the ensuing confrontation.{{cite news |url= http://www.abc.net.au/news/2014-12-16/sydney-siege-ends-martin-place-lindt-cafe/5969162 |title= Sydney siege: Two hostages and gunman dead after heavily armed police storm Lindt cafe in Martin Place |publisher= Australian Broadcasting Corporation |work= ABC News |date= 16 December 2014 |quote= Two hostages and the gunman at the centre of a 16-hour siege at a cafe in Sydney's CBD have been shot dead, police have confirmed. |accessdate= 15 December 2014}} Two of the hostages also died, several others were wounded, and a police officer suffered minor injuries.{{cite press release |url= http://www.police.nsw.gov.au/news/latest_releases?sq_content_src=%2BdXJsPWh0dHBzJTNBJTJGJTJGZWJpenByZC5wb2xpY2UubnN3Lmdvdi5hdSUyRm1lZGlhJTJGNDMxNDguaHRtbCZhbGw9MQ%3D%3D |title= Critical incident established following Martin Place siege |publisher= [[New South Wales Police Force]] |date= 16 December 2014 |location= Sydney |accessdate= 16 December 2014 |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://archive.is/20141215193054/http://www.police.nsw.gov.au/news/latest_releases?sq_content_src=%2BdXJsPWh0dHBzJTNBJTJGJTJGZWJpenByZC5wb2xpY2UubnN3Lmdvdi5hdSUyRm1lZGlhJTJGNDMxNDguaHRtbCZhbGw9MQ%3D%3D |archivedate= 15 December 2014 |df= dmy-all }} In a website posting prior to the hostage incident, Monis denied all the charges against him, calling them politically motivated, accusing the Iranian [[Ministry of Intelligence]] and Australia's ASIO of framing him.{{cite web |url= https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/australiaandthepacific/australia/11294514/Sydney-siege-gunman-named-as-Man-Haron-Monis.html |title= Sydney siege gunman named as Man Haron Monis |work= Telegraph.co.uk |date= 15 December 2014 |author= Jonathan Pearlman in Sydney |accessdate= 15 December 2014}} No one claimed Monis's body when it was released by the [[NSW Coroner]], and he was subsequently buried in an undisclosed NSW location at state expense.{{cite news|url=http://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/news/nsw/martin-place-siege-gunman-man-horan-monis-buried-in-undisclosed-location-in-nsw/story-fni0cx12-1227191950482 |title=Martin Place siege gunman Man Horan Monis buried in undisclosed location in NSW |publisher=The Daily Telegraph |date=21 January 2015 |accessdate=2015-09-11}} In 2016, Monis was listed under mentally disturbed individuals who have launched recent violent attacks justified with Islamist ideas or slogans. Other examples include the perpetrator of the 2016 [[Munich knife attack]] and Michael Zehaf-Bibeau, the perpetrator of the [[2014 shootings at Parliament Hill, Ottawa]]. According to psychologists and psychiatrists who study radicalisation, jihad propaganda and calls to kill the infidels can push mentally ill individuals to act, even in the absence of direct or personal contact with Islamists.{{cite news|title=Global terrorist groups exploit mentally ill people to carry out attacks|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/world/global-terrorist-groups-exploit-mentally-ill-people-to-carry-out-attacks-experts|accessdate=17 May 2016|agency=Agence France|publisher=Straits Times|date=12 May 2016}} ==Investigations== Prime Minister [[Tony Abbott]] was briefed by the Australian Federal Police on 16 December 2014 that Monis had a gun licence, but the AFP later confirmed that Monis "was not a registered firearms licence holder".{{cite web |title= Media Statement: Firearm licence status of Man Haron Monis |url= http://www.afp.gov.au/media-centre/news/afp/2014/december/media-statement-firearm-licence-status-of-man-haron-monis.aspx |publisher= [[Australian Federal Police]] |date= 18 December 2014 |accessdate= 18 December 2014}} A joint review has been announced by the federal and state governments, to be helmed by [[Michael Thawley]] from the [[Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet (Australia)|Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet]] and [[Blair Comley]] of the [[New South Wales Department of Premier and Cabinet]]. It will investigate the handling of the siege, and how Monis "slipped through state and federal security and legal nets".{{cite web |last1= Grattan |first1= Michelle |authorlink= Michelle Grattan |title= Joint review ordered into siege and hostage-taker’s background |url= https://theconversation.com/joint-review-ordered-into-siege-and-hostage-takers-background-35619 |publisher= The Conversation |date= 17 December 2014 |accessdate= 19 December 2014}} Although a call had been made to the national security hotline based on the contents of Monis' website, there were no threats of direct violence.{{cite news |last1= Safi |first1= Michael |title= Sydney siege: anonymous warning about Man Haron Monis followed up, says PM |url= https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2014/dec/21/sydney-siege-anonymous-warning-about-man-haron-monis-followed-up-says-pm |work= The Guardian |date= 21 December 2014 |accessdate= 22 December 2014}} On 16 December 2014, officers from the New South Wales Police Force and the [[Australian Federal Police]] went to the [[Belmore, New South Wales|Belmore]] home of Monis' partner Amirah Droudis, and removed property.{{cite news |last1= Higgins |first1= Ean |title= Police raid home of Haron partner Amirah Droudis |url= http://www.theaustralian.com.au/in-depth/police-raid-home-of-haron-monis-partner-amirah-droudis/story-fnqxbywy-1227158154165 |work= The Australian |date= 16 December 2014 |accessdate= 16 December 2014}}{{cite news |last1= Levy |first1= Megan |title= Bail review call for Amirah Droudis, partner of Sydney siege gunman Man Haron Monis |url= http://www.smh.com.au/nsw/bail-review-call-for-amirah-droudis-partner-of-sydney-siege-gunman-man-haron-monis-20141217-129gp7.html |work= The Sydney Morning Herald |date= 18 December 2014 |accessdate= 18 December 2014}} Her bail was revoked after a hearing on 22 December.{{cite news |title= Sydney siege gunman's partner Amirah Droudis has bail revoked |url= http://www.abc.net.au/news/2014-12-22/sydney-siege-gunman-partner-amirah-droudis-bail-revoked/5982674 |work= ABC News |date= 21 December 2014 |accessdate= 22 December 2014}} In November 2016 Droudis was found guilty, in a judge-only trial, of the murder of Monis' ex-wife.{{cite news |last1=MacMillan|first1=Jade |title=Sydney siege gunman's girlfriend found guilty of murder |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2016-11-03/amirah-droudis-guilty-murder-man-haron-monis-wife-2013/7991620 |accessdate=19 November 2016 |work=ABC News |publisher=Australian Broadcasting Corporation |date=3 November 2016}} On 29 January 2015, an [[Sydney siege inquest|inquest began into the deaths at the Lindt Cafe]], presided over by the NSW State Coroner, Michael Barnes. Its aim is "to determine how the [three] deaths occurred, the factors that contributed to them and whether they could have been prevented".{{cite web|last1=Barnes |first1=Michael (NSW State Coroner) |title=Press Release |url=http://www.coroners.justice.nsw.gov.au/agdbasev7wr/_assets/coroners/m401601l771003/press%20release_2014_12_16_11_22_25_127.pdf |website=[[Coroner's Court of New South Wales]] |publisher=Government of New South Wales |format=PDF |date=16 December 2014 |accessdate=23 December 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141223220139/http://www.coroners.justice.nsw.gov.au/agdbasev7wr/_assets/coroners/m401601l771003/press%20release_2014_12_16_11_22_25_127.pdf |archivedate=23 December 2014 |df= }}{{cite news |last1= Olding|first1= Rachel |title= Date revealed for inquest into Martin Place siege deaths |url= http://www.smh.com.au/nsw/date-revealed-for-inquest-into-martin-place-siege-deaths-20150113-12noya.html |work= The Sydney Morning Herald |date= 14 January 2015 |accessdate= 14 January 2015}}{{cite news |last1= Ryan|first1= Brad |title= Sydney siege inquest: Deaths of Katrina Dawson and Tori Johnson investigated as inquest opens |url= http://www.abc.net.au/news/2015-01-29/inquest-into-sydney-siege-opens/6053114 |publisher= Australian Broadcasting Corporation |date= 28 January 2015 |accessdate= 28 January 2015}} The joint State-Federal review was released on 22 February 2015.{{cite web|url= http://www.abc.net.au/news/2015-02-22/sydney-siege-joint-review-released-visa-citizenship-reforms/6184012|title= Sydney Lindt cafe siege: Tony Abbott says protecting the community will mean 'redrawing the line' on individual rights, after review released|publisher= Australian Broadcasting Corporation|author= James Bennett|date= page.title: Minister of the Navy and Postal Affairs

revision.text:
The '''Norwegian Minister of Navy and Postal Affairs''' was the head of the [[Norwegian Ministry of Navy and Postal Affairs]]. The position existed from 1815 to 1885, but was named Minister of the Navy and Postal Affairs only from 1861.
In 1861, the [[Norwegian Ministry of Postal Affairs|Ministry of Postal Affairs]] had been merged with the Ministry of the Navy. The Ministry of the Navy and Postal Affairs was regarded the direct successor. Before this, various other names were used.
==List of Norwegian Ministers of Navy and Postal Affairs== In 1815, the ministry was named the ''7th Ministry''.

{{Infobox MLA | name = Monty Davidson | image = Montgomery 'Monty' Bryden Davidson.jpg | caption = | office1 = [[Member of Provincial Parliament (Ontario)|Ontario MPP]] | term_start1 = 1975 | term_end1 = 1981 | predecessor1 = ''New riding'' | successor1 = [[Bill Barlow]] | constituency1 = [[Cambridge (provincial electoral district)|Cambridge]] | party = [[Ontario New Democratic Party|New Democrat]] |birth_name = Montgomery Bryden Davidson | birth_date = {{birth date|1935|10|23}} | birth_place = | death_date = {{death date and age|2017|3|26|1935|10|23|df=y}} | death_place = [[Cambridge, Ontario]] | residence = [[Cambridge, Ontario]] | occupation = Textile worker, Labour activist | spouse = Margaret | children = 6 }} '''Montgomery Bryden "Monty" Davidson''' (23 October 1935 – 26 March 2017) was Canadian politician. He served as a [[Ontario New Democratic Party|New Democratic]] [[Member of Provincial Parliament (Ontario)|member]] of the [[Legislative Assembly of Ontario]] for the riding of [[Cambridge (provincial electoral district)|Cambridge]] from 1975 until 1981.
==Background== Monty Davidson was a staff representative for the [[Textile Workers Union of America|Textile Workers of America]] and a long-time union organizer. He went to work, at the age of 15, for the Stauffer and Dobbie Co. textile plant in [[Galt, Ontario]] and became [[shop steward]] at the age of 17.<ref name=lab>{{cite news |title=Labouring on; Fewer industries means fewer unions, but times are changing, organizers say |newspaper=Kitchener-Waterloo Record |first=Dave |last=Pink |date=August 30, 2003 |page=J1}}</ref>
==Politics== In the [[Ontario general election, 1975|1975 provincial election]], Davidson ran as the [[Ontario New Democratic Party|NDP]] candidate in the new riding of [[Cambridge (provincial electoral district)|Cambridge]]. He defeated [[Ontario Liberal Party|Liberal]] candidate [[Claudette Millar]] by 1,593 votes.<ref name="1975 Election Results">{{cite news |title=Table of vote results for all Ontario ridings |newspaper=The Globe and Mail |date=September 19, 1975 |page=C12}}</ref> He was re-elected in [[Ontario general election, 1977|1977]] defeating [[Progressive Conservative Party of Ontario|Progressive Conservative]] candidate [[Bill Barlow]] by 554 votes.<ref name="1977 Election Results">{{cite news |title=Ontario provincial election results riding by riding |newspaper=The Globe and Mail |date=June 10, 1977 |page=D9}}</ref><ref name=form>{{cite news |title=Former Cambridge MPP hasn't lost taste for politics |last=Jalsevac |first=Philip |newspaper=Kitchener-Waterloo Record |date=February 26, 1993 |page=B3}}</ref> In the [[Ontario general election, 1981|1981]] election he again faced Barlow but lost to him by 849 votes.<ref name="1981 Election Results">{{cite news|author=Canadian Press |title=Winds of change, sea of security |newspaper=The Windsor Star |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=0NtYAAAAIBAJ&sjid=QlIMAAAAIBAJ&pg=1444%2C1388326 |date=March 20, 1981 |location=Windsor, Ontario |page=22}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Former Cambridge MPP Barlow to be honored by Tories, friends |newspaper=Kitchener-Waterloo Record |last=Aagaard |first=Chris |date=April 12, 1991 |page=B3}}</ref> During his time as an MPP, he sat in opposition under NDP leaders [[Stephen Lewis]] and [[Michael Cassidy (Canadian politician)|Michael Cassidy]].
==Later life== In 1981, he took a job with the Occupational Health and Safety Branch of the [[Ontario Federation of Labour]]. He said, "It's a full-time job and I'm very fortunate that there were people looking out for me who were willing to give me this kind of work in an area that I'm familiar with."<ref>{{cite news |title=The losers for ex-MPPs, it's limelight to limbo |last=Carriere |first=Vianney |newspaper=The Globe and Mail |date=August 24, 1981}}</ref> In his later career, he worked at the Workers Health and Safety Centre in Cambridge before retiring in 1999.<ref name=lab/>
Davidson died on March 26, 2017. He was survived by Margaret, his wife of 62 years, and six children. <ref>{{cite web |title=Montgomery "Monty" Davidson ~ 1935-2017 |url=http://www.corbettfuneralhome.ca/obituaries/115101 |publisher=Corbett Funeral Home}}</ref> The NDP association in Cambridge established an annual award in his memory "to celebrate [his] life-long service to working people". <ref>{{cite web |title=Cambridge NDP Presents New Monty Davidson Award at Oct. 14 Fall Dinner |url=http://cambridge-ndp.ca/beta-test/index.php/2016/07/18/join-us-at-cambridge-ndp-family-bbq-on-july-17-43-mcclintock-drive-lot-79/ |date=July 18, 2016 |publisher=Cambridge NDP}}</ref>

{{no footnotes|date=April 2014}} '''Mors Kochanski''' is a [[Polish Canadians|Polish Canadian]] [[bushcraft]] and [[wilderness]] [[Survival techniques|survival]] instructor, [[naturalist]] and author. He has acquired an international following and has instructed for both military and civilians in Canada, the US, the UK and Sweden. He is well known for saying "The more you know, the less you carry"
{{Infobox person | name = Mors Kochanski | image = Kochanski.JPG | caption = "The more you know, the less you carry" | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1940|11|10|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Saskatchewan, Canada]] | death_date = | death_place = | other_names = | known_for = [[Bushcraft]] and [[survival techniques]] | occupation = [[Survival and wilderness skills instructor]] and [[author]] | nationality = [[Canada|Canadian]] | homepage = [http://www.MorsKochanski.com/ MorsKochanski.com] | spouse = | children = }}
==Early life==
The Kochanski family immigrated to Canada from Poland in 1938 and Mors was born two years later (1940), the fifth of six children. His mother named him "Morris" but, because of a misunderstanding due to her Polish accent, the midwife wrote 'Mors' on the birth certificate. His father fought for the Polish Army, during the First World War. That experience left him with a strong desire to see his children educated, so that they might benefit from serving as officers. Mors' father felt that his children would inevitably be conscripted for military service, during a war in their lifetime.
Mors was brought up on a relatively isolated farm in Saskatchewan. He spent most of his time working the farm and assisting his father, who had been a windmill carpenter in Poland. In his early school years, he walked or rode 7 miles to and from school on a bush road. This daily journey was a significant part of his education and the foundation for a lifetime of interest in nature.
In 1954 his parents moved to Prince Albert and, freed from his farm chores, he made the public library his second home. Mors took particular interest in two books:
*An old Boy Scout manual - Mors lasted only one year as a Scout, due to disappointment in what he perceived as a lack of seriousness on the part of his fellow scouts and the Scout Master’s aversion to camp craft skills.
*[[The Ashley Book of Knots]] - Mors enlisted the help of the head Librarian, to order his own copy. At around $15 in 1952, it took him a long time to save enough money for purchase. So began a lifetime of collecting books on natural history, camping and survival skills, resulting in a personal library of thousands of titles.
Mors was a Sea Cadet for three years. He chose the Navy as a career and received a scholarship to the Canadian Services College, Royal Roads. While enrolled, he traveled by ship through the Panama Canal, in the summer of 1959. He was hospitalized for five weeks during his studies, predominantly due to a case of the mumps. This contributed to an honourable discharge in his second year, after failing too many subjects on the way to his Chemical Engineering degree.
From 1960 to 1964 he took Arts and Sciences at the University of Saskatchewan. Rather than enrolling in curriculum courses, Mors took classes that were of interest to him, including anthropology, psychology, geology and writing. His lack of participation in a recognised degree program resulted in a suspension from the university due to "a complete lack of direction", after four years.
==Professional career==
From that point on, he resolved to become a specialist in outdoor subjects, specialising in wilderness living skills and the lifestyles of wilderness peoples. However, Mors had many different jobs, before he found his opportunity to become an instructor. These include:
*Draughtsman - Updating the street plans of the City of Prince Albert after the installation of gas mains.
*Concrete Technician - Construction of water-excluding cribbing for a potash mine.
*Geologist Assistant - At an engineering firm, searching for an optimal location for a potash mine and exploring the feasibility of a solution mining approach in Saskatchewan.
*Engineering Technician - Involving a potash solution mine project.
*Surveyor - For the construction of roads in Saskatchewan.
*Social Worker
It was also around this time that he received a pilot’s license.
==Instructor career==
In 1968, Blue Lake Centre (near [[Hinton, Alberta|Hinton]], [[Alberta]]) began operating outdoor education programs. Mors, now 28 years of age, offered his services. At the same time, he met his friend and mentor, Tom Roycraft. At the time, Tom was the senior civilian survival instructor at a [[Department of National Defence (Canada)|Department of National Defence]] survival school.
During the 1970s Mors became an associate professor at the University of Alberta Faculty of Physical Education, editor of the magazine ‘Alberta Wilderness Arts and Recreation’ and performed [[freelance]] work for various agencies.
In 1986, he was approached to write a book on survival and wilderness skills for the Canadian [[boreal forest]]s which was originally titled "Northern Bushcraft". The book became a Canadian bestseller. The original title 'Northern Bushcraft' was in reference to an earlier publication 'Bushcraft' by [[Richard Harry Graves]], which covered survival and wilderness living skills in the Australian environment. Eventually, the publishers later shortened the title to 'Bushcraft'.
==List of publications==
*''Wilderness Arts and Recreation Magazine'' (editor and author, with Tom Roycraft and Don Bright of Edson, Alberta) - beginning in 1976. *''Bushcraft'' – originally released as ''Northern Bushcraft'' in 1988. A guide to outdoor skills and wilderness survival. (Lone Pine Publishing)(Northern Bushcraft - 1988 {{ISBN|1-871890-30-6}}) (Bushcraft - 1998 {{ISBN|1-55105-122-2}}) *''Bush Arts'' – a guide to hand crafting with materials from the boreal forest. Lone Pine Publishing, 1989 {{ISBN|0-919433-49-9}} *''Wilderness Skills Series'' and ''A Plant Walk with Mors Kochanski'' - (DVD series produced by Karamat Wilderness Ways) *''Booklet series'' (17+ tiles, inc. Basic Wilderness Skills in Deep Snow, Survival Kit Ideas, etc.) – published by Karamat Wilderness Ways *''Basic Safe Travel and Boreal Survival Handbook: Gems from Wilderness Arts and Recreation Magazine'' in 2013. A guide to outdoor skills and wilderness survival. (Publisher: Karamat Wilderness Ways, {{ISBN|978-1894453684}}) *''Grand Syllabus, Instructor Trainee Program: Survival, Wilderness Living Skills, Bushcraft'' in 2015. (Publisher: Karamat Wilderness Ways, {{ISBN|978-1894453677}})
==References== *''Northern Bushcraft'' (1988) {{ISBN|1-871890-30-6}} *''Bush Arts'' (1989) {{ISBN|0-919433-49-9}} *''Bushcraft'' (1998) {{ISBN|1-55105-122-2}} *''Basic Safe Travel and Boreal Survival Handbook'' (2013) {{ISBN|978-1894453684}} *''Grand Syllabus. Instructor Trainee Program'' (2015) {{ISBN|978-1894453677}}
